page.intro: These TEAL Center fact sheets will provide some background knowledge and help you put the concepts into the context of adult education teaching.
page.content:
These TEAL Center fact sheets will provide some background knowledge and help you put the concepts into the context of adult education teaching:

Differentiated Instruction, an approach that enables instructors to plan strategically to meet the needs of every learner. The approach encompasses planning and delivery of instruction, classroom management techniques, and expectations of learners’ performance that take into consideration the diversity and varied levels of readiness, interests, and learning profiles of learners.

Student-centered Learning, an approach to learning in which learners choose not only what to study but also how and why. At the heart of the learning environment are learning responsibility and activity, in contrast to the emphasis on instructor control and coverage of academic content found in conventional, didactic teaching.

Technology-Supported Writing Instruction. Using technology to support instruction in writing is undeniably important in the digital age. It is also a key evidence-based method for supporting struggling writers. But which technologies support which components of writing instruction? This fact sheet provides an overview of the various types of writing tools. 

Math Instruction

Three principles to differentiation in instruction are:

  1. Respectful tasks that begin at the levels students are currently, and which allow them to grow.
  2. Flexible groupings that allow students to work on different tasks simultaneously, or work with students at their level, or work with students at different levels.
  3. Ongoing assessment by teachers to determine strengths and struggles.

These principles are taken from Martin, H. (2006). Differentiated Instruction for mathematics: Instructions and activities for the diverse classroom. Walch Publishing.

Using technology in the math classroom is one method to differentiate instruction, providing different representations of material and multiple entry points for students at different levels.

Technology Supported Math Instruction

Technology can be useful in the following scenarios: 

  • Keeping track of a budget
  • Checking bills for accuracy
  • Deciding on whether to refinance a home
  • Analyzing choices on whether to trade in a car or not
  • Planning a vacation
  • Decorating or designing a room
  • Finding resources, directions, and designs for wood working , painting, home repairs, cooking, sewing, and more

Tools

  • Common Core State Standards for Mathematics: Standards for Mathematical Practice
  • Adding it Up: Helping Children Learn Mathematics
  • ThirteenEd Online
  • Computing Technology for Math Excellence
  • NCTM – Core Math Tools: General Purpose Tools

  • Floor Planner

  • National Library of Virtual Manipulatives
